message: I don't know. Is it really social? There is almost no user generated content or communication within members. Does not feel social to me.
Isn't 'social shopping' what Groupon and such do?
hmm next big thing - 'real time' social discovery using "some-wireless-technology"(tm) =)
Is it Social Shopping?
definitely Convore
Convore!
It's not "gamification"? :P
@frangucc very meta
I think social shopping is a huge opportunity, but I don't think anyone's done it right yet. Not sure what the right way to do it is, but I'm working on it :)
something mobile that is highly personal
@jharsem Awesome! When does it launch?!
@micrypt just as soon as they find a EULA tight enough to deal with the whole lawsuit due to human on slingshot issue.
@micrypt ok then =) .. 'real time' social discovery using "some-wireless-technology"(tm) for the purposes of playing Angry Birds XI =)
It's all ball bearings these days
Someone really needs to make a real-time chat application. I don't know, focused on group communication or something like that.
convore

sites that integrate social media (not just "like" buttons). think reading an article on a site and seeing alongside what your facebook friends commented about it. or having a convore chat stream about that article. ideas go on...
@michaelschade if you're serious, you should check out Yobongo.com
@waynesutton I think he was talking about Convore
@waynesutton But I've heard good things about Yobongo.com.  I'm curious why it'll succeed when others (like message party) failed.
@ericflo ok, I think the way the app works with connecting people by location for new conversations will make yobongo succeed plus people are ready for something different

the next big thing is cloud based programming ide
with a good editor
git integration etc
we'd like to make a lisp based ide for the cloud
with the ability to make a software without writing any code
how can ide in cloud be next big thing if your userbase is not going to be more than 10% of total internet users?
it might be quite valuable
abstract syntax trees ftw
easy to draw with a touch screen
if we get some way to code with ipads :)
The next big thing is certainly not guessing what the next big thing will be.
@ pimeys wait, don't mess the thread
but that was just a crazy idea
that's just the idea
yeah, I also prefer writing code
so you can draw the tree
@pimeys I'd much rather type code than draw a tree but I'd be happy to try it :)
lisp would be ideal for that, the trees can be transferred to lisp very easily
you can freeze the tree and make a commit to git etc.
@pimeys why not a great *front-end* ?
don't know if it's gonna work
then just save all the diffs to mongo etc. and you may check your workmates diffs and connect the trees
@waynesutton @kashif Haha yeah, was talking about Convore ;)

@waynesutton Would be curious also though what Yobongo has over MessageParty. It's an interesting area at least, a friend and I drafted the architecture for a similar location-based, group chatting system when bored the other day.
@pimeys why does everyone always want to make software without writing code? I want more people to write code.
@puredanger me too :)
but lisp would be a great backend for that kind of system
because all the code is a kind of tree
and I'm thinking of coding with the iPad
when we talked about how to program without writing code
and back to trees of course
and how all the products doing that just... sucks

These days I'm concentrating less on the next big thing... and more on "what actually helps people". Startups that improve the world make me happy - (e.g. khan academy)
http://kottke.org/09/06/big-ideas-from-silly-to-obvious
Economist Lant Pritchett's model for game changing ideas is "Crazy. Crazy. Crazy. Obvious." He revised to, "Silly, controversial, progressive, then obvious."
I'd argue any idea will fit in the spectrum. Twitter was silly. It's not obvious yet, but quite progressive.
I heard Formspring is adding a "Question" button, kinda like Facebook's "Like" button, which is supposed to be spread across all websites for easily asking questions to people
I think the next big thing is cake. Lots of chocolate cake.

@micrypt Limburger?
irc.
iphone 5
Just look at Apple. They get it.
@mal Quite possibly. I'm still waiting till TC covers Limburger. Only then will we know for sure.
The next big thing when It comes to software is cloud-services via application downloaded from the Mac App Store.

I've never thought that Apple had any clue what the next big thing was; I do however think they leveraged a horde of a existing loyal fans in what is the most successful use of viral marketing to date. Directly or indirectly, they tell YOU what the next big thing is.
@devn I really wished that was true...
@mal Agreed.

@mal Apple is a customer driven company. They are also good at identifying trends and what's next. And the question was: what is next? IMHO look at Apple... and even Google for that matter. Well, perhaps I see things more objectivly then you do.
"Apple is a customer driven company." - do you really think so?
@carlhblomqvist Sounds suspiciously like subjective Apple loyalist speak to me! As for what's next; I reckon transparent devices, or at least the illusion of, augmented reality type stuff.
I just got back from Twitter and it seems the next big thing definitely has something to do with "bots". Sentient bots... O_O
@mal Oh, it's already begun: http://twitpic.com/3ua2n8 I bet they are planning a printer-led siege.
When they all start talking to each other without us, Skynet will have arrived!
Twitter is gaining a lot of traction. Maybe that's the next big thing!
sounds noob
I'm sorry

@mal People still believe this? Just as an example of Apple'he iPhone paved the way for what smartphone interfaces would look like. Even if you believe that it was loyal Apple fans who bought the first version (at a $600 price and with no third-party apps!), one look at Android's massive success in adopting the IPhone's UX design and bringing it to a more open platform shows that Apple was definitely the ones who understood where that market had to go. (remember, Android was originally envisioned to go on a wide range of devices, the first press conference showed androids that looked like blackberries and androids that looked like cheap featurephones.  Now they are all large touchscreen devices, just like the iPhone)

@mal hey, don't be rude. Agumented reality is a hard nut to crack to make good. Most user don't even know how to use it. So no, I don't think that's the next big thing. The same goes with virtual reality IMO.
and face / place recognition with overlays
augmented reality will really take off when you can get glasses with a small camera and HUD
android app on your phone powering it
I was thinking more small scale; camera phone view finder + labels to start, perhaps arrows pointing you to your destination.
@carlhblomqvist Perhaps, but you do at least see the irony of your having an opinion that your view point is more objective than mine, right? ;D
